timeline.bodyText: Fix this comment as swap space is internally managed.
timeline.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: Unrelated to this PR - it would be nice to have a getOrElse method for alluxio conf
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: If these two have the same functionality, could we keep the same property name? evictor.class is not misleading?
timeline.author: calvinjia
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -2272,9 +2272,12 @@ public String toString() {
           .setConsistencyCheckLevel(ConsistencyCheckLevel.WARN)
           .setScope(Scope.WORKER)
           .build();
+  /**
+   * @deprecated use block annotators instead
+   */

replies.bodyText: It's not exactly the same functionality. And keeping them separate simplifies emulation decision.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: is supposed to be visible for -> is only visible to
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: Add TODO here to run multiple tasks in parallel?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: At this level I don't intend to run things in parallel as each task here is I/O bound. I believe it's good to have priority based preemption here. Tasks themselves should spawn concurrent tasks though.
replies.author: ggezer

replies.bodyText: If we don't plan to run tasks in parallel, do we still need to submit to another threadpool?
replies.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText:
It's a single-thread-executor.
It can be useful to keep a separate thread pool for the future in case we want to let some tasks run in parallel if not all.
replies.author: ggezer

replies.bodyText: Actually, after working on concurrency, I think it's simpler to run tasks on coordinator thread. We can change If we want to allow multiple tier management tasks later.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: Is it okay to have this thread running by itself, should we keep track of it?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: Closing this now as part of block-worker shutdown.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: Should we log this, I don't think its unexpected? Maybe we can increment some metric to keep track of how many failed allocations we had.
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: Is this concept necessary, it seems a bit too much of a heuristic?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText:
This concept is a fail-safe against a corner case:

Worker reached peak capacity
Annotator is LRFU
Concurrent readers/writers

In this case, each allocation could end up sorting the whole block list in order to find eviction candidate. This is due to LRFU being an online scheme. If CPU starts burning, we could evict more than necessary using this prop and avoid excessive sorting per allocation.
This should be mentioned in the tuning guides.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: Should we do a check if dirView is null here and do our failure handling (ie. log message now but I suggest to increment some metric)?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: Currently, as per previous trend, callers all throw/log for null response from this method. I think metrics would be fine. However I was planning an all over work on defining new metrics. It can be done at the end of this PR or as a separate PR.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: return null here?
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: We can name it streamList directly?
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: The logic of *Opened and *Closed are the same, perhaps abstract to another method?
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: Could we do the cooldown in ManagementTaskCoordinator instead of emulating it here?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: ManagementTaskCoordinator also have a cool down. However, it's required to implement the cool-down outside of coordinator as each task also need to track load by itself.
replies.author: ggezer

replies.bodyText: Could you elaborate on this a bit more? Does the LoadTracker need to understand the load per task (ie. so we can do storage directory level throttling) or just whether or not there has been load?
replies.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText:
LoadTracker needs to figure out if there was an external (user I/O) on a particular directory.
So it will be used by tasks to figure out if the directory that they're working on is under load, then back-off.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: After this method, we only hint at what kind of task is necessary but not the details of the task. What is the computation cost here and could we do more computation to pass onto the execution of the task (ie. which blocks to swap)? Also since the swap will happen at a different time, are there any consistency issues?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText:
Consistency is loose based on ConcurrentSkipListSet's iterator consistency. So decision given by this method, or the later swap-list that is acquired could no longer be valid. In that case, next run is supposed to fix that. However, with load tracking, inconsistency will not be vast and will be sorted out on next run.
As for the computations, this method's heaviest lift is the BlockIterator:overlaps method which is not directly translatable. I wouldn't worry about the wasted work here as overlap will be detected at first block comparison at a tier intersection.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: When will there be no oldValue, does it make sense to set the clock value to 0 (most recent)?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText:
There will be no oldValue when the block is seen the first time. Recency is by having greater values, so 0 means the least recent.
Assumption here is that a block will first be committed, and have its value annotated as 0. Value will be bumped only when it's accessed after commit.
replies.author: ggezer

replies.bodyText: Is this typical for LRU algorithms, or should the block have highest recency on commit?
replies.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText:
This was the default in LRUEvictor.
I believe this could potentially be a configuration property.
replies.author: ggezer
calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: Can you add some implications, or when one would want it to be true or false?
timeline.author: gpang

replies.bodyText:
This is when there is no management required VS back-ing off to come back again.
Here because checking if management is required has its own cost. However I'm inclined to just reuse the cool-down for this purpose.
replies.author: ggezer

replies.bodyText: It is pretty confusing. I think we will need to add more details to this parameter (possibly explicitly contrasting it with the other one), or getting rid of one of them.
replies.author: gpang

replies.bodyText: Cut this one.

replies.bodyText:
This controls concurrency at the disk level. I try to limit the disks we're spinning using this.
Needs a better name for sure.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: What are the implications to setting this to true or false?

+          .setDescription("Whether to use file-system moves to "

replies.bodyText: I didn't want to introduce another variable through already complex rpc layer.

replies.bodyText: this API is no more.

replies.bodyText: No. The purpose of this API is to retain the lock after returning from this. They both use commitBlockInternal though
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: Is RuntimeException the correct exception to throw? Can we provide more information in the message?
timeline.author: gpang

replies.bodyText: This API is no more.

replies.bodyText: This API is no more.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: why is this now synchronized?
timeline.author: gpang

replies.bodyText: It now only removes blocks and shouldn't run concurrently as per allocation guarantees.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText:
Should this be warn?
Also, it is always the case that the block doesn't exist right? The message sounds like the eviction failed, and one possible reason is that the block is already gone.
timeline.author: gpang

replies.bodyText:
Yes.
It's printed out when we want to remove a block, based on annotations, and that block was not there. It can happen if block annotator is out of sync with the store.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: Do we need to make sure it is not too small either?
timeline.author: gpang

replies.bodyText: I feel like that would require another prop to get a test pass.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: could you add a comment mentioning why this method has to be synchronized.
timeline.author: gpang

timeline.bodyText: does this need mUseReservedSpace? Also affects equals() and toString().
timeline.author: gpang

timeline.bodyText: "available' and "committed" all fit within "capacity". Is this also true for "reserved"? Can we a comment (maybe a class comment) describing the relationship between all of these types of bytes?
timeline.author: gpang

timeline.author: gpang

timeline.bodyText: should we also mention "sleeping X ms"?
timeline.author: gpang

timeline.message: Replace async eviction with on-demand eviction
Manage coordinator thread shutdown + minor fixes
Implicit reserved space management + Remove swap API
Reimplement freeSpace() to free contigious space

timeline.bodyText:
this::getUpdatedView
Is this mostly for backward compatibility, in the new model do we still need to have evictor views?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: Yes, we still make use of them.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: contiguousSpaceFound
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: Do we care about availableBytesFound? It seems like the only satisfactory condition is contigiousSpaceFound
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: Does this need to be updated over the course of this method?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: No. Especially considering it's very lightweight now (only deletes) compared to before.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: We don't need any locks for this?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText:
freeSpaceInternal() is only called by allocateSpace() which is required to be called with meta-write lock acquired.
We actually don't need this API in BlockWorker anymore so I deprecated it.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: What is this lock intended to guard against? It looks like BlockTransferExecutor is never shared among threads?
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: Does this class need locking on top of the concurrent data structures? Which methods we expect to be called concurrently and what are the guarantees for mPerDirOrderedSets?
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.bodyText: It seems possible this will be modified concurrently during iteration?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText:
I think you mean the storageLost() callback. Nice catch.
Updated to a concurrent-map.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: For block updated and block removed, do we need to notify the block annotator?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText:
For updates, we need the annotator to give the block a new annotated value.
For removes, no need to invoke the annotator.
replies.author: ggezer

timeline.bodyText: Could you clarify the responsibilities of this class? What is the division of work between this class and DefaultBlockIterator?
timeline.author: calvinjia

timeline.message: Treat commit as access on LRU annotator
